Multi-Message Shuffled Privacy in Federated Learning

Antonious M. Girgis and Suhas Diggavi
University of California, Los Angeles, USA.
Email: amgirgis@g.ucla.edu, suhas@ee.ucla.edu
Abstract

We study differentially private distributed optimization under communication constraints. A server using SGD for optimization, aggregates the client-side local gradients for model updates using distributed mean estimation (DME). We develop a communication efficient private DME, using the recently developed multi-message shuffled (MMS) privacy framework. We analyze our proposed DME scheme to show that it achieves the order-optimal privacy-communication-performance tradeoff resolving an open question in [1], whether the shuffled models can improve the tradeoff obtained in Secure Aggregation. This also resolves an open question on optimal trade-off for private vector sum in the MMS model. We achieve it through a novel privacy mechanism that non-uniformly allocates privacy at different resolutions of the local gradient vectors. These results are directly applied to give guarantees on private distributed learning algorithms using this for private gradient aggregation iteratively. We also numerically evaluate the private DME algorithms.

I Introduction

In federated learning (FL) distributed nodes collaborate to build learning models, mediated by a server111This is because no client has access to enough data to build rich learning models locally and we do not want to directly share local data.. In particular, they collaboratively build a learning model by solving an empirical risk minimization (ERM) problem (see (5) in Section II). Even though local data is not directly shared, such a collaborative interaction does not provide any privacy guarantee. Therefore, the objective is to solve (5) while enabling strong privacy guarantees on local data from the server, but with good learning performance, i.e., a suitable privacy-learning performance operating point. Differential Privacy (DP) [2], is the accepted theoretical framework for formal privacy guarantees. Though DP was proposed for central data storage, the appropriate framework for privacy with distributed (local) data is local differential privacy (LDP) [3, 4], where even the mediating server is not trusted for privacy. Another important aspect is that communication in FL occurs in bandwidth limited (wireless) links, this communication bottleneck can be significant in modern large-scale machine learning. The overall goal of this paper is to develop (both theory and algorithms) for the fundamental privacy-communication-performance trade-off to solve the ERM in (5) for FL.

Private distributed mean estimation (DME) and optimization: At the core of solving the ERM in (5) through (stochastic) gradient descent (SGD) is to aggregate the local gradients, which is equivalent to finding the (distributed) mean of the users’ gradients. Therefore, the central problem is to study the privacy-communication-performance trade-off for DME. Since there are repeated interactions via iterations of SGD, each exchange leaks information about the local data, but we need as many steps as possible to obtain a good model; setting up the tension between privacy and performance. The objective is to obtain as many such interactions as possible for a given privacy budget. This is quantified through analyzing the privacy of the composition of privacy mechanisms as a function of the number of iterations, and such tight analyses have been developed for composition in [5, 6]. We use compositional bounds from [7, 8] in conjunction with our new private DME mechanisms to obtain the privacy-communication-performance trade-off for solving (5) (see Theorem 13).

Privacy frameworks: A strong privacy guarantee includes an untrustworthy server, and to guarantee this, in LDP each client randomizes its interactions with the server from whom the data is to be kept private (e.g., see implementations  [9, 10]). The fundamental privacy-communication-performance trade-offs of LDP mechanisms for private DME have been recently studied [11, 12]. We study a new approach to the privacy-communication-performance trade-off (see Theorems 2, 4 which are also order optimal, and we adapt it for other privacy frameworks below.

LDP mechanisms suffer from poor performance in comparison with the central DP mechanisms [3, 13]. In order to overcome this, two privacy frameworks have been advocated, which enable significantly better privacy-performance trade-offs by amplifying privacy: (i) Secure Aggregation (SecAgg): This is a secure sum protocol [14] which only allows the server to see the sum of vectors, and not individual ones. (ii) Shuffled model: Each user sends her private message to a secure shuffler that randomly permutes all the received messages before forwarding them to the server [15, 16]. The extension to this is the multi-message shuffled (MMS) model, where there are multiple parallel shuffled models as above. In [17, 18] it has been shown that one can get significantly better trade-offs with such multi-message shuffled (MMS) models. In this paper we focus on such multi-message shuffled (MMS) privacy models.

Contributions: Motivated by these discussions, we make the following contributions.

  • •

    In [1], a (order-wise) fundamental trade-off for privacy-communication-performance was established for DME for the SecAgg privacy framework, and an open question was posed on this trade-off for the shuffled models. In this paper we resolve this question through a fundamental privacy-communication-performance trade-off for DME in the (multi-message) shuffled (MMS) models, for all regimes; we believe ours is the first scheme to achieve the complete optimal trade-off (see Theorems 3, 5) which matches lower bound (see Theorem 6). Furthermore, we show that our MMS requires less amount of communication per client than used in the SecAgg to achieve the same order of MSE (See Remark 3).

  • •

    In [17, 18], it was shown that for computing scalar sum in multi-message shuffled (MMS) models can fundamentally achieve trade-off points that single-message shuffled models cannot. The optimal trade-off for computing vector sum is an open question, and the only known result [19] has communication per-user growing as 𝒪​(d​n)𝒪𝑑𝑛\mathcal{O}(d\sqrt{n}), where n𝑛n is number of users and d𝑑d is the vector dimension. In this paper we establish the fundamental privacy-communication-performance trade-off for computing vector sum in the multi-message shuffled model (see Theorems 3, 5) for all trade-off regimes, which order-wise is better than the results in [19]. In doing so, we also resolve this trade-off for all regimes in the scalar case (see Remark 1).

  • •

    Our scheme when applied to LDP, also achieves the optimal trade-off for this privacy framework (see Theorems 2, 4), similar to [11, 12] and (order-wise) better performance than [20] when applied to LDP. (see Remark 4). Since the idea of [20] was used as a primitive in [1], we can plug in our method to potentially improve the trade-off in their scheme.

  • •

    We use the results for optimal private DME to analyze privacy-convergence trade-offs of the DP-SGD algorithm (similar to algorithms in [12, 19] in Theorem 13.

  • •

    In Section VI, we evaluate the performance of our proposed algorithms for scalar and vector private DME.

The core technical idea that enables these results is the following. Suppose each client i𝑖i holds a real vector 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}, and we want to privately compute the sum ∑i𝐱isubscript𝑖subscript𝐱𝑖\sum_{i}\mathbf{x}_{i}. First we devise a co-ordinate sampling mechanism related to the target communication desired, independently for each client; then we compute the private scalar sum ∑i∈𝒜k𝐱i​[k]subscript𝑖subscript𝒜𝑘subscript𝐱𝑖delimited-[]𝑘\sum_{i\in\mathcal{A}_{k}}\mathbf{x}_{i}[k], where 𝐱i​[k]subscript𝐱𝑖delimited-[]𝑘\mathbf{x}_{i}[k] is the k𝑘k-th co-ordinate, and 𝒜ksubscript𝒜𝑘\mathcal{A}_{k} is the set of clients that sampled the k𝑘k-th co-ordinate. We can express 𝐱i​[k]=0.𝐛i(1)​𝐛i(2)​…,𝐛i(m)​…formulae-sequencesubscript𝐱𝑖delimited-[]𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖2…superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑚…\mathbf{x}_{i}[k]=0.\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(1)}\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(2)}\ldots,\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(m)}\ldots in binary form222We have written this for 𝐱i​[k]∈[0,1]subscript𝐱𝑖delimited-[]𝑘01\mathbf{x}_{i}[k]\in[0,1] but can be easily extended to any bounded values, i.e., ‖𝐱i‖∞≤r∞subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑟\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\|_{\infty}\leq r_{\infty}., where 𝐛i(j)∈{0,1}superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑗01\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(j)}\in\{0,1\}. For privacy, we randomize each bit through a binary randomized response [21], but we randomize each bit with a different privacy budget, so that we meet an overall privacy budget. This careful choice of such non-uniform randomization is key to our method. Moreover, for communication constraints we represent it with finite m𝑚m bits (see more details in Section IV). We can either use this overall randomization as is, for LDP, or send each bit through a separate shuffler for multi-message shuffling (MMS). Then by carefully accounting for the composition using RDP, we obtain our privacy guarantees and performance (see Lemmas 3, 4). This simple mechanism yields explicit bounds for the complete trade-off and forms the core of our solution.

I-A Related Work

We give the most relevant work related to the paper and review some of their connections to our work.

Private DME:

In [11, 12] the privacy-communication-performance tradeoff were studied both through schemes as well as lower bounds for the local DP model. [11] established the order optimal private DME under local DP model for bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vectors. [12] established order optimal private DME for local DP for bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm and separately for bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vectors. It also extended its use in the single-shuffled model and private optimization framework (see below). In [22, 23], a family of communication-efficient mechanisms is proposed under LDP constraints in federated learning.

In the multi-message shuffled (MMS) model, the private scalar DME was studied in [17, 18], where order optimal strategies were established. The private vector DME has received less attention, with the exception of [19]. Our private vector DME result in Theorem 5 improves the privacy-communication-performance order-wise over it. In [20, 1], the privacy-communication-performance trade-off in the SecAgg privacy model was studied. In particular, using ideas from compressive sensing, [1] established an order-optimal private DME for SecAgg.

Private optimization in the shuffled model:

There has been a lot of work on private optimization in the local model, see [24, 12] and references therein. We will focus on private optimization in the shuffled model, where there is relatively less work. Recently [25] and [12, 26] have proposed DP-SGD algorithms for federated learning, in the shuffled model, where at each iteration, each client applies an LDP mechanism on the gradients. [27] studied a private optimization framework using RDP and additionally evaluated subsampling (of clients) in the shuffled model. The approach in  [25] was to send full-prevision gradients without compression, but  [12, 27] did use compression for the gradients. These methods achived certain optimal privacy-communication-performance operating points, but not in all regimes. The use of RDP for establishing compositional bounds for interactive optimization was studied in [7, 8], which is used in establishing the privacy bounds for iterative stochastic optimization. All these were for the single-shuffle model. For the multi-message shuffled (MMS) model, private optimization was studied in [19], which at its core used a private vector DME with MMS. As explained earlier, our private vector DME is orderwise better than this scheme, and if we plug our scheme into the standard convergence analyses for optimization, we obtain better results as also given in Appendix F.

Paper organization: We formulate the problem, establish notation and some preliminary results in Section II. We present an overview of the algorithms and the main theoretical results in Section IV. The technical proof ideas are outlined in Section V. Some numerical results are presented in Section VI. The proof details are given in the appendices.

II Preliminaries

We give privacy definitions in Section II-A and the binary randomized response in Section II-B.

II-A Privacy Definitions

In this section, we define different privacy notions that we will use in this paper: local differential privacy (LDP), central different privacy (DP), and Renyi differential privacy (RDP). We also give standard results on privacy composition as well as conversion between privacy notions.

Definition 1 (Local Differential Privacy - LDP [3]).

For ϵ0≥0subscriptitalic-ϵ00\epsilon_{0}\geq 0, a randomized mechanism ℛ:𝒳→𝒴:ℛ→𝒳𝒴\mathcal{R}:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y} is said to be ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-local differentially private (in short, ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP), if for every pair of inputs d,d′∈𝒳𝑑superscript𝑑′𝒳d,d^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}, we have

Pr⁡[ℛ​(d)∈𝒮]≤eϵ0​Pr⁡[ℛ​(d′)∈𝒮],∀𝒮⊂𝒴.formulae-sequencePrℛ𝑑𝒮superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ0Prℛsuperscript𝑑′𝒮for-all𝒮𝒴~{}\Pr[\mathcal{R}(d)\in\mathcal{S}]\leq e^{\epsilon_{0}}\Pr[\mathcal{R}(d^{\prime})\in\mathcal{S}],\qquad\forall\mathcal{S}\subset\mathcal{Y}. (1)

Let 𝒟={d1,…,dn}𝒟subscript𝑑1…subscript𝑑𝑛\mathcal{D}=\{d_{1},\ldots,d_{n}\} denote a dataset comprising n𝑛n points from 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. We say that two datasets 𝒟={d1,…,dn}𝒟subscript𝑑1…subscript𝑑𝑛\mathcal{D}=\{d_{1},\ldots,d_{n}\} and 𝒟′={d1′,…,dn′}superscript𝒟′superscriptsubscript𝑑1′…superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑛′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}=\{d_{1}^{\prime},\ldots,d_{n}^{\prime}\} are neighboring (and denoted by 𝒟∼𝒟′similar-to𝒟superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime}) if they differ in one data point, i.e., there exists an i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] such that di≠di′subscript𝑑𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑑′𝑖d_{i}\neq d^{\prime}_{i} and for every j∈[n],j≠iformulae-sequence𝑗delimited-[]𝑛𝑗𝑖j\in[n],j\neq i, we have dj=dj′subscript𝑑𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑑′𝑗d_{j}=d^{\prime}_{j}.

Definition 2 (Central Differential Privacy - DP [2, 28]).

For ϵ,δ≥0italic-ϵ𝛿0\epsilon,\delta\geq 0, a randomized mechanism ℳ:𝒳n→𝒴:ℳ→superscript𝒳𝑛𝒴\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathcal{Y} is said to be (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private (in short, (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP), if for all neighboring datasets 𝒟∼𝒟′∈𝒳nsimilar-to𝒟superscript𝒟′superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n} and every subset 𝒮⊆𝒴𝒮𝒴\mathcal{S}\subseteq\mathcal{Y}, we have

Pr⁡[ℳ​(𝒟)∈𝒮]≤eϵ0​Pr⁡[ℳ​(𝒟′)∈𝒮]+δ.Prℳ𝒟𝒮superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ0Prℳsuperscript𝒟′𝒮𝛿~{}\Pr\left[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{S}\right]\leq e^{\epsilon_{0}}\Pr\left[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{S}\right]+\delta. (2)
Definition 3 ((α,ϵ​(α))𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼(\alpha,\epsilon(\alpha))-RDP (Renyi Differential Privacy) [6]).

A randomized mechanism ℳ:𝒳n→𝒴:ℳ→superscript𝒳𝑛𝒴\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathcal{Y} is said to have ϵ​(α)italic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon(\alpha)-Renyi differential privacy of order α∈(1,∞)𝛼1\alpha\in(1,\infty) (in short, (α,ϵ​(α))𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼(\alpha,\epsilon(\alpha))-RDP), if for any neighboring datasets 𝒟∼𝒟′∈𝒳nsimilar-to𝒟superscript𝒟′superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D}\sim\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}, we have that Dα(ℳ(𝒟)||ℳ(𝒟′))≤ϵ(α)D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D})||\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq\epsilon(\alpha), where Dα(P||Q)D_{\alpha}(P||Q) denotes the Renyi divergence between two distributions P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q defined by:

The RDP provides a tight privacy accounting of adaptively composed mechanisms. The following result states that if we adaptively compose two RDP mechanisms with the same order, their privacy parameters add up in the resulting mechanism.

Lemma 1 (Adaptive composition of RDP [6]).

For any α>1𝛼1\alpha>1, let ℳ1:𝒳→𝒴1:subscriptℳ1→𝒳subscript𝒴1\mathcal{M}_{1}:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y}_{1} be a (α,ϵ1​(α))𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ1𝛼(\alpha,\epsilon_{1}(\alpha))-RDP mechanism and ℳ2:𝒴1×𝒳→𝒴:subscriptℳ2→subscript𝒴1𝒳𝒴\mathcal{M}_{2}:\mathcal{Y}_{1}\times\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y} be a (α,ϵ2​(α))𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝛼(\alpha,\epsilon_{2}(\alpha))-RDP mechanism. Then, the mechanism defined by (ℳ1,ℳ2)subscriptℳ1subscriptℳ2(\mathcal{M}_{1},\mathcal{M}_{2}) satisfies (α,ϵ1​(α)+ϵ2​(α))𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ1𝛼subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝛼(\alpha,\epsilon_{1}(\alpha)+\epsilon_{2}(\alpha))-RDP.

We use the following result for converting the RDP guarantees of a mechanism to its DP guarantees.

Lemma 2 (From RDP to DP [29, 30]).

Suppose for any α>1𝛼1\alpha>1, a mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is (α,ϵ​(α))𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼\left(\alpha,\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\right)-RDP. For any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, the mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is (ϵδ,δ)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝛿𝛿\left(\epsilon_{\delta},\delta\right)-DP, where ϵδsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝛿\epsilon_{\delta} is given by:

ϵδ=minα⁡ϵ​(α)+log⁡(1/δ)α−1+log⁡(1−1/α)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝛿subscript𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼1𝛿𝛼111𝛼\displaystyle\epsilon_{\delta}=\min_{\alpha}\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)+\frac{\log\left(1/\delta\right)}{\alpha-1}+\log\left(1-1/\alpha\right)

II-B Binary Randomized Response (2RR)

The binary randomized response (2RR) is one of the most popular private mechanism that first proposed in [21]. We present an unbiased version of the 2RR mechanism in Algorithm 1 whose input is a bit b∈{0,1}𝑏01b\in\{0,1\} and the output can take one of two values {−p1−2​p,1−p1−2​p}𝑝12𝑝1𝑝12𝑝\{\frac{-p}{1-2p},\frac{1-p}{1-2p}\}, where p𝑝p controls privacy-accuracy trade-offs. Furthermore, we present the mean square error (MSE) of the 2RR in the following Theorem.

Theorem 1.

For any p∈[0,1/2)𝑝012p\in[0,1/2), the 2RR is ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP, where ϵ0=log⁡(1−pp)subscriptitalic-ϵ01𝑝𝑝\epsilon_{0}=\log\left(\frac{1-p}{p}\right). The output y𝑦y of the 2RR mechanism is an unbiased estimate of b𝑏b with bounded MSE:

𝖬𝖲𝖤2RR=supb∈{0,1}𝔼​[‖b−y‖22]=p​(1−p)(1−2​p)2.superscript𝖬𝖲𝖤2RRsubscriptsupremum𝑏01𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑏𝑦22𝑝1𝑝superscript12𝑝2~{}\mathsf{MSE}^{\textsl{2RR}}=\sup_{b\in\{0,1\}}\mathbb{E}\left[\|b-y\|_{2}^{2}\right]=\frac{p(1-p)}{(1-2p)^{2}}. (4)

For completeness, we present the proof of Theorem 1 in Appendix A.

III Problem formulation

We consider a distributed private learning setup comprising a set of N𝑁N clients, where the i𝑖ith client has a data set 𝒱isubscript𝒱𝑖\mathcal{V}_{i} for i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in\left[N\right]. Let 𝒟=(𝒱1,…,𝒱N)𝒟subscript𝒱1…subscript𝒱𝑁\mathcal{D}=\left(\mathcal{V}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{V}_{N}\right) denote the entire training dataset, with 𝒱isubscript𝒱𝑖\mathcal{V}_{i} held locally by user i𝑖i. The clients are connected to an untrusted server in order to solve the following empirical risk minimization (ERM) problem

minθ∈𝒞⁡(F​(θ,𝒟):=1N​∑i=1N∑𝐯∈𝒱if​(θ,𝐯)),subscript𝜃𝒞assign𝐹𝜃𝒟1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝐯subscript𝒱𝑖𝑓𝜃𝐯\min_{\theta\in\mathcal{C}}\Big{(}F(\theta,\mathcal{D}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\sum_{\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{V}_{i}}f(\theta,\mathbf{v})\Big{)}, (5)

where 𝒞⊂ℝd𝒞superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is a closed convex set, 𝐯∈𝒱𝐯𝒱\mathbf{v}\in\mathcal{V}, and f:𝒞×𝒱→ℝ:𝑓→𝒞𝒱ℝf:\mathcal{C}\times\mathcal{V}\to\mathbb{R}, is the loss function. Our goal is to construct a global learning model θ𝜃\theta via stochastic gradient descent (SGD) while preserving privacy of individual data points in the training dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} by providing strong DP guarantees. SGD can be written as

θt+1←θt−ηt​1n​∑i∈ℐℛ​(∇fi​(θt)),←subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡1𝑛subscript𝑖ℐℛ∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t+1}\leftarrow\theta_{t}-\eta_{t}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\mathcal{R}(\nabla f_{i}(\theta_{t})),

where ℛℛ\mathcal{R} is the local randomization mechanism and ℐℐ\mathcal{I} are the indices of the clients partipating in that round of SGD, with n=|ℐ|𝑛ℐn=|\mathcal{I}|. Therefore, at each iteration the server does distributed mean estimation (DME) of the gradients 1n​∑i∈ℐℛ​(∇fi​(θt))1𝑛subscript𝑖ℐℛ∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝜃𝑡\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\mathcal{R}(\nabla f_{i}(\theta_{t})), and we want it to be done privately and communication-efficiently. To isolate this problem we define DME under privacy and communication constraints. Suppose we have a set of n𝑛n clients. Each client has has a d𝑑d dimensional vector 𝐱i∈𝒳subscript𝐱𝑖𝒳\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{X} for i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], where 𝒳⊂ℝd𝒳superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{X}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} denotes a bounded subset of all possible inputs. For example, 𝒳≜𝔹2d​(r2)≜𝒳subscriptsuperscript𝔹𝑑2subscript𝑟2\mathcal{X}\triangleq\mathbb{B}^{d}_{2}(r_{2}) denotes the d𝑑d dimensional ball with radius r2subscript𝑟2r_{2}, i.e., each vector 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} satisfies ‖𝐱i‖2≤r2subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖2subscript𝑟2\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\|_{2}\leq r_{2} for i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]. Furthermore, each client has a communication budget of b𝑏b-bits. The clients are connected to an (untrusted) server that wants to estimate 𝐱¯=∑i=1n𝐱i¯𝐱superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐱𝑖\overline{\mathbf{x}}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{x}_{i}.

Privacy frameworks: We assume an untrusted server, under two different privacy models: (i) Local DP (LDP) model (ii) Multi-message shuffled (MMS) model.

LDP-model: We design two mechanisms: (i) client-side mechanism ℛ:𝒳→𝒴:ℛ→𝒳𝒴\mathcal{R}:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y} and (ii) Server aggregator 𝒜:𝒴n→ℝd:𝒜→superscript𝒴𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{Y}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}. The local mechanism ℛℛ\mathcal{R} takes an input 𝐱i∈𝒳subscript𝐱𝑖𝒳\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{X} and generates a randomized output 𝐲i∈𝒴subscript𝐲𝑖𝒴\mathbf{y}_{i}\in\mathcal{Y}. The local mechanism ℛℛ\mathcal{R} satisfies privacy and communication constraints as follows. The output 𝐲i=ℛ​(𝐱i)subscript𝐲𝑖ℛsubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{y}_{i}=\mathcal{R}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right) can be represented using only b𝑏b-bits. The mechanism ℛℛ\mathcal{R} satisfies ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP (see Definition 1). Each client sends the output 𝐲isubscript𝐲𝑖\mathbf{y}_{i} directly to the server, which applies the aggregator 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} to estimate the mean 𝐱^=𝒜​(𝐲1,…,𝐲n)^𝐱𝒜subscript𝐲1…subscript𝐲𝑛\hat{\mathbf{x}}=\mathcal{A}\left(\mathbf{y}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{y}_{n}\right) such that the estimated mean 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} is an unbiased estimate of the true mean 𝐱¯¯𝐱\overline{\mathbf{x}}.

MMS-model: The single shuffle model is similar to the local DP model but with a secure shuffler (permutation) which anonymizes the clients to the server; shuffling can amplify the privacy of the algorithm. Precisely, the shuffle model consists of three parameters (ℛ,𝒮,𝒜)ℛ𝒮𝒜\left(\mathcal{R},\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A}\right): (i) Encode: a set of local mechanisms ℛ(k):𝒳→𝒴,k=1,…,m:superscriptℛ𝑘formulae-sequence→𝒳𝒴𝑘1…𝑚\mathcal{R}^{(k)}:\mathcal{X}\to\mathcal{Y},k=1,\ldots,m each similar to the local DP model. Each client sends the m𝑚m outputs 𝐲i(k),k=1,…,mformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑘𝑘1…𝑚\mathbf{y}_{i}^{(k)},k=1,\ldots,m, where 𝐲i(k)∈𝒴superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑘𝒴\mathbf{y}_{i}^{(k)}\in\mathcal{Y}, to the secure shufflers. (ii) Multi-message Shuffle: a single secure shuffler 𝒮k:𝒴n→𝒴n:subscript𝒮𝑘→superscript𝒴𝑛superscript𝒴𝑛\mathcal{S}_{k}:\mathcal{Y}^{n}\to\mathcal{Y}^{n} receives n𝑛n outputs 𝐲i(k),i=1,…,nformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖𝑘𝑖1…𝑛\mathbf{y}_{i}^{(k)},i=1,\ldots,n after applying the local mechanism ℛ(k)superscriptℛ𝑘\mathcal{R}^{(k)} on each input 𝐱1,…,𝐱nsubscript𝐱1…subscript𝐱𝑛\mathbf{x}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{n} and generates a random permutation π(k)superscript𝜋𝑘\pi^{(k)} of the received messages. The multi-message shuffle is a parallel set of m𝑚m single-message shufflers {𝒮k}subscript𝒮𝑘\{\mathcal{S}_{k}\}. (iii) Analyze: the server receives the m𝑚m shufflers’ outputs and applies the aggregator 𝒜:𝒴n​m→ℝd:𝒜→superscript𝒴𝑛𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{Y}^{nm}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} to estimate the mean 𝐱^=𝒜(𝐲π(k)​(1),…,𝐲π(k)​(n),k=1,…,m)\hat{\mathbf{x}}=\mathcal{A}\left(\mathbf{y}_{\pi^{(k)}(1)},\ldots,\mathbf{y}_{\pi^{(k)}(n)},k=1,\ldots,m\right). We say that the shuffled model is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP if the view of the output of the multi-message shuffler (𝐲π(k)​(1),…,𝐲π(k)​(n),k=1,…,m)formulae-sequencesubscript𝐲superscript𝜋𝑘1…subscript𝐲superscript𝜋𝑘𝑛𝑘1…𝑚\left(\mathbf{y}_{\pi^{(k)}(1)},\ldots,\mathbf{y}_{\pi^{(k)}(n)},k=1,\ldots,m\right) satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP.

In the two privacy models, the performance of the estimator 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} is measured by the expected loss:

𝖬𝖲𝖤=sup{𝐱i∈𝒳}𝔼​[‖𝐱^−𝐱¯‖22],𝖬𝖲𝖤subscriptsupremumsubscript𝐱𝑖𝒳𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm^𝐱¯𝐱22~{}\mathsf{MSE}=\sup_{\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{X}\}}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\hat{\mathbf{x}}-\overline{\mathbf{x}}\|_{2}^{2}\right], (6)

where the expectation is taken over the randomness of the private mechanisms. Hence, our goal is to design communication-efficient and private schemes to generate an unbiased estimate of the true mean x¯¯𝑥\overline{x} while minimizing the expected loss (6). We study the DME for bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm i.e., ‖𝐱i‖∞≤r∞subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑟\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\|_{\infty}\leq r_{\infty} for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] and for bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vectors where ‖𝐱i‖2≤r2subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖2subscript𝑟2\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\|_{2}\leq r_{2}.

IV Overview and main theoretical results

In this section we give an overview of our algorithmic solution for private DME and the theoretical guarantees for two important cases of boundedness constraints on the individual vectors. We consider the private DME of bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm vectors in Section IV-A and that for bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vectors in Section IV-B. We will use these results to provide the guarantees for solving the trade-off for the ERM problem of (5) in the Appendix F (Theorem 13).

IV-A Bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm vectors

We consider privately computing ∑i=1n𝐱isuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐱𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{x}_{i} where i𝑖ith client has a vector 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} such that ‖𝐱i‖∞≤r∞subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑟\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\|_{\infty}\leq r_{\infty} for i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]. For ease of operation, we will scale each vector such that each coordinate becomes bounded in range [0,1]01\left[0,1\right], and then reverse it at the end. To make our mechanism communication efficient, each client approximates the vector 𝐳isubscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}_{i} by using the first m𝑚m binary vectors {𝐛i(k):1≤k≤m}conditional-setsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑘1𝑘𝑚\{\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(k)}:1\leq k\leq m\}. For completeness, we prove some properties of this quantization scheme in Appendix C.

The private DME mechanism is given in Algorithm 2, where v𝑣v controls the total privacy of the mechanism. There are two communication parameters: m𝑚m controls the number of bits for quantization and s𝑠s controls the number of dimensions used to represent each binary vector. In Theorems 2 and  3, we present how the privacy and communication parameters v,m,s𝑣𝑚𝑠v,m,s affects the accuracy of the mechanism. The server-side is presented in Algorithm 3. The server estimate the mean of each binary vectors {bi(k)}superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑖𝑘\{b_{i}^{(k)}\} and decodes the messages to generate an estimate to true mean 𝐳¯=1n​∑i=1n𝐳i¯𝐳1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐳𝑖\overline{\mathbf{z}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{z}_{i}. Then, the server scales the vector 𝐳¯¯𝐳\overline{\mathbf{z}} to generate an unbiased estimate of the mean 𝐱¯¯𝐱\overline{\mathbf{x}}.

We prove the bound on the MSE of the proposed mechanisms in the local DP and MMS models in the following theorems, where we defer the proofs to Appendix D. For ease of presentation, we provide the order of the achievable MSE and give the ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP and/or central (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP guarantees of our mechanism for both local DP and shuffle models. We track the constants in the MSE in the detailed proofs in Appendix D, see (45), (47). Furthermore, we present RDP guarantees of our mechanisms for both local DP and MMS models in the detailed proofs. We give the outline of the proofs in Section V.

Remark 1 (Scalar case).

When d=1𝑑1d=1, i.e., scalar case, our MMS algorithm achieves the central DP error 𝒪​(1n2​ϵ2)𝒪1superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{n^{2}\epsilon^{2}}\right) using m=⌈log⁡(n​ϵ2)⌉𝑚𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2m=\lceil\log\left(n\epsilon^{2}\right)\rceil bits per user. This result covers the private-communication trade-offs for all privacy regimes ϵ∈(0,1)italic-ϵ01\epsilon\in(0,1). For example, for ϵ=1nitalic-ϵ1𝑛\epsilon=\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}, each client needs only a single bit to achieve the central DP error. On the other hand, IKOS mechanism proposed in [31, 32] requires 𝒪​(log⁡(n))𝒪𝑛\mathcal{O}\left(\log\left(n\right)\right)-bits of communication. Even when particular regimes of order-optimality are achieved for MMS, the communication bound is in expectation [33],, whereas ours is deterministic.

IV-B Bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm Vectors

For private DME ∑i=1n𝐱isuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐱𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{x}_{i} where ‖𝐱i‖2≤r2subscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑖2subscript𝑟2\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\|_{2}\leq r_{2} for i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], i.e., ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-bounded, we use the random rotation proposed in [34] to bound the ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm of the vector with radius r∞=𝒪​(r2d)subscript𝑟𝒪subscript𝑟2𝑑r_{\infty}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{r_{2}}{\sqrt{d}}\right) and then we apply the bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm algorithm in Section IV-A.

Theorem 4 (Local DP model).

The output of the local mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s} can be represented using s​m​(log⁡(⌈d/s⌉)+1)𝑠𝑚𝑑𝑠1sm\left(\log\left(\lceil d/s\rceil\right)+1\right) bits. By choosing v=ϵ0𝑣subscriptitalic-ϵ0v=\epsilon_{0}, the mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s} satisfies ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP. Let 𝐱^^𝐱\hat{\mathbf{x}} be the output of the analyzer 𝒜ℓ2superscript𝒜subscriptℓ2\mathcal{A}^{\ell_{2}}. Remark 2 (Kashin’s represention).

Observe that the MSE in (12) has a factor of (log⁡(n​d))𝑛𝑑\left(\log(nd)\right) that comes from using the random rotation matrix. We can remove this factor log⁡(n​d)𝑛𝑑\log(nd) by using the Kashin’s representation [35] to transform the bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vector into a bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm vector (see e.g., [36, 37, 11])

Remark 3 (Comparison with SecAgg).

When d<n​ϵ2𝑑𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2d<n\epsilon^{2}, our MMS algorithm requires 𝒪​(d​log⁡(n​ϵ2d))𝒪𝑑𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑑\mathcal{O}\left(d\log\left(\frac{n\epsilon^{2}}{d}\right)\right) bits per client to achieve the central DP error 𝒪​(dn2​ϵ2)𝒪𝑑superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{d}{n^{2}\epsilon^{2}}\right). Furthermore, it requires only 𝒪​(n​ϵ2​log⁡(dn​ϵ2))𝒪𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑑𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2\mathcal{O}\left(n\epsilon^{2}\log\left(\frac{d}{n\epsilon^{2}}\right)\right)-bits when d>n​ϵ2𝑑𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2d>n\epsilon^{2}. On the other hand DDG algorithm [20] need 𝒪​(d​log⁡(n))𝒪𝑑𝑛\mathcal{O}\left(d\log\left(n\right)\right)-bits when d<n2​ϵ2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ2d<n^{2}\epsilon^{2} and 𝒪​(n2​ϵ2​log⁡(n))𝒪superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑛\mathcal{O}\left(n^{2}\epsilon^{2}\log\left(n\right)\right)-bits when d>n2​ϵ2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ2d>n^{2}\epsilon^{2} [1] to achieve the same MSE. Hence, the MMS saves communication in comparison with SecAgg.

Remark 4 (Compatability with SecAgg).

When choosing s=d𝑠𝑑s=d, the output of our algorithm ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s} can be represented as m𝑚m binary-vectors. Hence, it is compatible with secure aggregation to compute the sum of these vectors. Thus, using our ℛv,m,dℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑑\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,d} with SecAgg gives the same privacy-communication trade-offs as the MMS model in Theorem 5, since SecAgg can be seen as a post-processing of shuffling. However, our algorithm needs d​⌈log⁡(n​ϵ2d)⌉𝑑𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑑d\lceil\log\left(\frac{n\epsilon^{2}}{d}\right)\rceil-bits per client to achieve the central error of 𝒪​(dn2​ϵ2)𝒪𝑑superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ2\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{d}{n^{2}\epsilon^{2}}\right). On the other hand, the distributed-discrete-Gaussian in [20] needs 𝒪​(d​log⁡(n))𝒪𝑑𝑛\mathcal{O}\left(d\log\left(n\right)\right)-bits per client to achieve the same MSE.

Next we present a lower bound for DME under privacy and communication constraints, which can be derived using results from [1] and  [38].

Theorem 6 (Lower Bound For central DP model).

Let n,d∈ℕ𝑛𝑑ℕn,d\in\mathbb{N}, ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, r2≥1subscript𝑟21r_{2}\geq 1, and δ=o​(1n)𝛿𝑜1𝑛\delta=o(\frac{1}{n}). For any 𝐱1,…,𝐱n∈𝔹2d​(r2)subscript𝐱1…subscript𝐱𝑛superscriptsubscript𝔹2𝑑subscript𝑟2\mathbf{x}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{n}\in\mathbb{B}_{2}^{d}(r_{2}), the MSE is bounded below by:

𝖬𝖲𝖤centralℓ2=Ω​(r22​max⁡{dn2​ϵ2,1n​4b/d})superscriptsubscript𝖬𝖲𝖤centralsubscriptℓ2Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝑟22𝑑superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝑛superscript4𝑏𝑑\mathsf{MSE}_{\text{central}}^{\ell_{2}}=\Omega\left(r_{2}^{2}\max\left\{\frac{d}{n^{2}\epsilon^{2}},\frac{1}{n4^{b/d}}\right\}\right) (13)

for any unbiased algorithm ℳℳ\mathcal{M} that is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP with b>d𝑏𝑑b>d-bits of communication per client. Furthermore, when b<d𝑏𝑑b<d bits per client, the MSE is bounded below by:

𝖬𝖲𝖤centralℓ2=Ω​(r22​d​max⁡{1n2​ϵ2,1n​b})superscriptsubscript𝖬𝖲𝖤centralsubscriptℓ2Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝑟22𝑑1superscript𝑛2superscriptitalic-ϵ21𝑛𝑏\mathsf{MSE}_{\text{central}}^{\ell_{2}}=\Omega\left(r_{2}^{2}d\max\left\{\frac{1}{n^{2}\epsilon^{2}},\frac{1}{nb}\right\}\right) (14)
Remark 5.

(Optimality of our mechanism) When the communication budget b>d𝑏𝑑b>d, we can see that our MSE in Theorem 5 matches the lower bound in 6 (up to logarithmic factor) by choosing s=d𝑠𝑑s=d and m=b/d𝑚𝑏𝑑m=b/d. Furthermore, when the communication budget b<d𝑏𝑑b<d, our algorithm achieve the lower bound by choosing s=b𝑠𝑏s=b and m=1𝑚1m=1. Thus, our algorithm for MMS is order optimal for all privacy-communication regimes.

V Proof outlines

As can be seen from (7), and Algorithm 2, the main ingredient is to solve the following sub-problem. Suppose, each client has a binary vector 𝐛i∈{0,1}dsubscript𝐛𝑖superscript01𝑑\mathbf{b}_{i}\in\{0,1\}^{d}. The goal is to privately compute the sum 𝐛¯=1n​∑i=1n𝐛i¯𝐛1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐛𝑖\overline{\mathbf{b}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{b}_{i} under privacy and communication constraints. If we can demonstrate a solution to this problem, then we can apply it to bounded-norm vectors as in Sections IV-A and IV-B using (7), along with another critical ingredient, to judiciously allocate the overall privacy budget among these bit-vectors describing the vectors at different resolution. These are the two main ideas that enable us to get the main theoretical results.

V-A Binary vectors

A straightforward solution to compute 𝐛¯=1n​∑i=1n𝐛i¯𝐛1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝐛𝑖\overline{\mathbf{b}}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{b}_{i}, is to apply the scalar solution proposed in  [16] for each coordinate. However, this requires d𝑑d bits per client. We will design private mechanisms with much less communication budget per client.

The client-side mechanism is presented in Algorithm 6, where the parameter s𝑠s determines the communication budget for each client and the parameter p𝑝p determines the total privacy budget (see Theorem 7). For given s∈{1,…,d}𝑠1…𝑑s\in\{1,\ldots,d\}, each client splits the binary vector 𝐛isubscript𝐛𝑖\mathbf{b}_{i} into s𝑠s sub-vectors each with dimension a=⌈ds⌉𝑎𝑑𝑠a=\lceil\frac{d}{s}\rceil. Then, the client chooses uniformly at random one coordinate from each sub-vector and privatizes its bit using 2RR Algorithm 1. Observe that the output of Algorithm 6 can be represented as a sparse d𝑑d-dimensional vector with only s𝑠s non-zero bits.

When s=1𝑠1s=1, then each client applies the 2RR mechanism on each coordinate separately. On the other hand, when s=d𝑠𝑑s=d, the client chooses uniformly at random one coordinate and applies the 2RR mechanism. Thus, we get trade-offs between privacy-communication and accuracy. The server aggregator 𝒜Binsuperscript𝒜Bin\mathcal{A}^{\text{Bin}} is presented in Algorithm 7, where the server simply aggregates the received randomized bits.

In the following theorems, we prove the bound on the MSE of the proposed mechanisms in the local DP and shuffle models. The proofs are deferred to Appendix B. For ease of presentation, we provide the order of the achievable MSE and give the ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP and/or central (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP guarantees of our mechanism for both local DP and shuffle models. However, we track the constants in the MSE in the detailed proofs in Appendix B. Furthermore, we present RDP guarantees of our mechanisms for both local DP and shuffle models in the detailed proofs.

V-B Putting things together

We start with proof outlines for Theorems 2 and  3. For both, the local randomization is the same, and the basic idea is that of non-uniform randomization of the different bits used to quantize a real vector 𝐳isubscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}_{i}, arising from (7). In particular, we use distinct randomizations for each bit vector 𝐛i(k)∈{0,1}dsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑘superscript01𝑑\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(k)}\in\{0,1\}^{d}, with different parameters pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} causing different privacy for each resolution level k𝑘k. For a given local privacy guarantee of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}, we divide this into guarantees ϵ0(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑘\epsilon_{0}^{(k)} for the k𝑘k-th resolution level, such that ϵ0=∑k=1mϵ0(k)subscriptitalic-ϵ0superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑘\epsilon_{0}=\sum_{k=1}^{m}\epsilon_{0}^{(k)}. The intuition is that one allocates higher privacy (lower ϵ0(k)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑘\epsilon_{0}^{(k)}) to the MSBs (lower k𝑘k), for a given overall privacy budget ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}. This is because to get better accuracy (performance in terms of MSE) we want the higher-order bits to be less noisy than the lower-order bits. We connect this non-uniform choice to the MSE for the LDP and MMS privacy models below.

Lemma 3 (Non-uniform privacy allocation).

Consider m𝑚m privacy mechanisms for {𝐛i(k)∈{0,1}d},𝐮isuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑘superscript01𝑑subscript𝐮𝑖\{\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(k)}\in\{0,1\}^{d}\},\mathbf{u}_{i} denoted by ℛp1,sBin​(𝐛i(1)),…,ℛpm−1,sBin​(𝐛i(m−1)),ℛpm,sBin​(𝐮i)subscriptsuperscriptℛBinsubscript𝑝1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖1…subscriptsuperscriptℛBinsubscript𝑝𝑚1𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑚1subscriptsuperscriptℛBinsubscript𝑝𝑚𝑠subscript𝐮𝑖\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p_{1},s}(\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(1)}),\ldots,\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p_{m-1},s}(\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(m-1)}),\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p_{m},s}(\mathbf{u}_{i}), parametrized by {pi}subscript𝑝𝑖\{p_{i}\}. For a given total privacy allocation of the choice of v=△ϵ0superscript△𝑣subscriptitalic-ϵ0v\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\epsilon_{0}, the choice of vk=△ϵ0(k)=4−k3(∑l=1m−14−l3+4−m+13)​vsuperscript△subscript𝑣𝑘superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑘superscript4𝑘3superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑚1superscript4𝑙3superscript4𝑚13𝑣v_{k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\epsilon_{0}^{(k)}=\frac{4^{\frac{-k}{3}}}{\left(\sum_{l=1}^{m-1}4^{\frac{-l}{3}}+4^{\frac{-m+1}{3}}\right)}v for k∈[m−1]𝑘delimited-[]𝑚1k\in[m-1] and vm=4−m+13(∑l=1m−14−l3+4−m+13)​vsubscript𝑣𝑚superscript4𝑚13superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑚1superscript4𝑙3superscript4𝑚13𝑣v_{m}=\frac{4^{\frac{-m+1}{3}}}{\left(\sum_{l=1}^{m-1}4^{\frac{-l}{3}}+4^{\frac{-m+1}{3}}\right)}v, we can get the following LDP and MMS models’ RDP-privacy guarantees:

ϵLDP​(α)subscriptitalic-ϵLDP𝛼\displaystyle\epsilon_{\text{LDP}}\left(\alpha\right) =∑k=1mϵLDP(k)​(α)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵLDP𝑘𝛼\displaystyle=\sum_{k=1}^{m}\epsilon_{\text{LDP}}^{(k)}\left(\alpha\right) (17)
ϵMMS​(α)subscriptitalic-ϵMMS𝛼\displaystyle\epsilon_{\text{MMS}}\left(\alpha\right) =∑k=1mϵMMS(k)​(α)≤c​α​v2s​nabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵMMS𝑘𝛼𝑐𝛼superscript𝑣2𝑠𝑛\displaystyle=\sum_{k=1}^{m}\epsilon_{\text{MMS}}^{(k)}\left(\alpha\right)\leq c\frac{\alpha v^{2}}{sn} (18)

for some constant c𝑐c and ϵLDP(k)(α)≤sα−1log(pkα\epsilon_{\text{LDP}}^{(k)}\left(\alpha\right)\leq\frac{s}{\alpha-1}\log\Big{(}p^{\alpha}_{k} (1−pk)1−α+pk1−α(1−pk)α)(1-p_{k})^{1-\alpha}+p^{1-\alpha}_{k}(1-p_{k})^{\alpha}\Big{)} (see Appendix D for details).

This lemma immediately yields the central DP guarantees of ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0} for the LDP model, and a (ϵMMS,δ)subscriptitalic-ϵMMS𝛿\left(\epsilon_{\text{MMS}},\delta\right)-DP, for the MMS model, where ϵMMSsubscriptitalic-ϵMMS\epsilon_{\text{MMS}} is bounded by

ϵMMS≤2​c​ϵ02​log⁡(1/δ)s​n,subscriptitalic-ϵMMS2𝑐superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ021𝛿𝑠𝑛~{}\epsilon_{\text{MMS}}\leq 2c\sqrt{\frac{\epsilon_{0}^{2}\log(1/\delta)}{sn}}, (19)

which suggests setting ϵ02=s​n​ϵ24​log⁡(1/δ)superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02𝑠𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ241𝛿\epsilon_{0}^{2}=\frac{sn\epsilon^{2}}{4\log(1/\delta)}, for the local randomization. Critically, this choice of non-uniform privatization enables the following result, proved in Appendix D.

Lemma 4 (MSE performance).

With the non-uniform privacy allocation specified in Lemma 3, we get the the following LDP and MMS models’ MSE performance for DME:

𝖬𝖲𝖤LDPℓ∞subscriptsuperscript𝖬𝖲𝖤subscriptℓLDP\displaystyle\mathsf{MSE}^{\ell_{\infty}}_{\text{LDP}} ≤𝒪​(r∞2​d2n​max⁡{1d​4m,1s,sϵ02})absent𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑟2superscript𝑑2𝑛1𝑑superscript4𝑚1𝑠𝑠superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{r_{\infty}^{2}d^{2}}{n}\max\left\{\frac{1}{d4^{m}},\frac{1}{s},\frac{s}{\epsilon_{0}^{2}}\right\}\right) (20)
𝖬𝖲𝖤MMSℓ∞subscriptsuperscript𝖬𝖲𝖤subscriptℓMMS\displaystyle\mathsf{MSE}^{\ell_{\infty}}_{\text{MMS}} ≤𝒪​(r∞2​d2n2​max⁡{nd​4m,n​(1s−1d),log⁡(1/δ)ϵ2})absent𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑟2superscript𝑑2superscript𝑛2𝑛𝑑superscript4𝑚𝑛1𝑠1𝑑1𝛿superscriptitalic-ϵ2\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{r_{\infty}^{2}d^{2}}{n^{2}}\max\left\{\frac{n}{d4^{m}},n\left(\frac{1}{s}-\frac{1}{d}\right),\frac{\log\left(1/\delta\right)}{\epsilon^{2}}\right\}\right) (21)

Theorem 2 follows from (20) and Theorem  3 follows from (19) and (21). Theorems 4, 5 directly follow by using Theorem 10 in Appendix E in  2 and  3.

VI Numerical Results

In this section, we evaluate the performance of our algorithms in the local DP model and the shuffle model.

VI-A Local DP model

We start by comparing the performance of our algorithm ℛv,m,sℓ​∞subscriptsuperscriptℛℓ𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell{\infty}}_{v,m,s} with the performance of the Laplace mechanism [1] in the local model for scalar case, i.e., d=1𝑑1d=1. Hence, the elements 𝐱i∈[−1,1]subscript𝐱𝑖11\mathbf{x}_{i}\in[-1,1]. Observe that the Laplace mechanism is the optimal scheme is this case, however, it has infinite communication bits. In Figure 1(a), we plot the MSE of our ℛv,m,sℓ​∞subscriptsuperscriptℛℓ𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell{\infty}}_{v,m,s} with different communication budget s=1𝑠1s=1 and m∈{1,2,3,4}𝑚1234m\in\{1,2,3,4\} for a single client n=1𝑛1n=1. We can observe that our mechanism achieves MSE closer to the MSE of the Laplace mechanism. Furthermore, we only need at most m=3𝑚3m=3 bits to achieve similar performance as Laplace mechanism.

VI-B Shuffler model

We consider two cases in the shuffler model: 1) The scalar case when d=1𝑑1d=1 to evaluate the performance of our ℛv,m,sℓ​∞subscriptsuperscriptℛℓ𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell{\infty}}_{v,m,s} mechanism in the shuffle model. 2) The vector case when d=1000𝑑1000d=1000 to evaluate the performance of our ℛv,m,sℓ​2subscriptsuperscriptℛℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell{2}}_{v,m,s} mechanism in the shuffle model.

Scalar

In Figure 1(b), we plot the MSE of two different mechanisms versus the central privacy ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon for fixed δ=10−5𝛿superscript105\delta=10^{-5}. The first mechanism is single message shuffle (SMS) obtained using Laplace mechanism with privacy amplification results in . Observe that Laplace mechanism is the optimal LDP mechanism for LDP and the privacy amplification results in [39] is approximately optimal for (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP. Hence, we expect that this is the best that an SMS mechanism can achieve. The second mechanism is our multi-message shuffling (MMS) mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ​∞subscriptsuperscriptℛℓ𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell{\infty}}_{v,m,s} mechanism for d=1𝑑1d=1 and m∈{4,6}𝑚46m\in\{4,6\}. Since we have MMS, we use the RDP results of privacy amplification by shuffling in [7] which is better for composition to compute the RDP of our mechanism. Then, we transform from RDP bound to approximate (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP. We choose number of clients n=1000𝑛1000n=1000. We can see that our multi-message shuffle model achieve lower MSE than the single message shuffle especially for large value of central DP parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

Bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vectors

Similar to the scalar case, we consider two mechanisms. The first mechanism SMS is obtained by using privunit mechanism with the privacy amplification results in [39], where privunit [40] is asymptotically optimal LDP mechanism [41]. We choose n=1000𝑛1000n=1000 and d=300𝑑300d=300. For our MMS ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s}, we choose s∈{200,250}𝑠200250s\in\{200,250\}. It is clear from Figure 1(c) that our MMS mechanism has better performance than SMS mechanism.

Appendix A Binary Randomized Response

In this section we review an unbiased version of the classical binary randomized response (2RR mechanism) in Algorithm 1. We also gather some results on the classical binary randomized response, which will be useful for our proofs.

Theorem 9 (Repeating Theorem 1).

For any p∈[0,1/2)𝑝012p\in[0,1/2), the 2RR is ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP, where ϵ0=log⁡(1−pp)subscriptitalic-ϵ01𝑝𝑝\epsilon_{0}=\log\left(\frac{1-p}{p}\right). The output y𝑦y of the 2RR mechanism is an unbiased estimate of b𝑏b with bounded MSE:

𝖬𝖲𝖤2RR=supb}∈{0,1𝔼​[‖b−y‖22]=p​(1−p)(1−2​p)2.~{}\mathsf{MSE}^{\textsl{2RR}}=\sup_{b\}\in\{0,1}\mathbb{E}\left[\|b-y\|_{2}^{2}\right]=\frac{p(1-p)}{(1-2p)^{2}}. (22)

Proof of Theorem 1 (The MSE of the 2RR) First, we show that the output of Algorithm 1 is unbiased estimate of b𝑏b. Let y𝑦y be the output of the 2RR Algorithm 1. Then, we have

𝔼​[y]𝔼delimited-[]𝑦\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[y\right] =b−p1−2​p​(1−p)+1−b−p1−2​p​pabsent𝑏𝑝12𝑝1𝑝1𝑏𝑝12𝑝𝑝\displaystyle=\frac{b-p}{1-2p}(1-p)+\frac{1-b-p}{1-2p}p (23)
=b​(1−2​p1−2​p)−p​(1−p)1−2​p+p​(1−p)1−2​pabsent𝑏12𝑝12𝑝𝑝1𝑝12𝑝𝑝1𝑝12𝑝\displaystyle=b\left(\frac{1-2p}{1-2p}\right)-\frac{p(1-p)}{1-2p}+\frac{p(1-p)}{1-2p}
=b.absent𝑏\displaystyle=b.

Hence, the Algorithm 1 is an unbiased estimate of the input b𝑏b. Furthermore, the MSE of the 2RR is bounded by:

𝖬𝖲𝖤2RRsuperscript𝖬𝖲𝖤2RR\displaystyle\mathsf{MSE}^{\textsl{2RR}} =𝔼​[‖y−b‖2]=𝔼​[y2]−b2absent𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝑦𝑏2𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑦2superscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left[\|y-b\|^{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[y^{2}\right]-b^{2} (24)
=1(1−2​p)2​[(b−p)2​(1−p)+(1−b−p)2​p]−b2absent1superscript12𝑝2delimited-[]superscript𝑏𝑝21𝑝superscript1𝑏𝑝2𝑝superscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{(1-2p)^{2}}\left[(b-p)^{2}(1-p)+(1-b-p)^{2}p\right]-b^{2}
=1(1−2​p)2​[b2−4​p​(1−p)​b+p​(1−p)]−b2absent1superscript12𝑝2delimited-[]superscript𝑏24𝑝1𝑝𝑏𝑝1𝑝superscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{(1-2p)^{2}}\left[b^{2}-4p(1-p)b+p(1-p)\right]-b^{2}
=1(1−2​p)2​[b2−4​p​(1−p)​b+p​(1−p)]−b2absent1superscript12𝑝2delimited-[]superscript𝑏24𝑝1𝑝𝑏𝑝1𝑝superscript𝑏2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{(1-2p)^{2}}\left[b^{2}-4p(1-p)b+p(1-p)\right]-b^{2}
=1(1−2​p)2​[b2​(4​p​(1−p))−4​p​(1−p)​b+p​(1−p)]absent1superscript12𝑝2delimited-[]superscript𝑏24𝑝1𝑝4𝑝1𝑝𝑏𝑝1𝑝\displaystyle=\frac{1}{(1-2p)^{2}}\left[b^{2}(4p(1-p))-4p(1-p)b+p(1-p)\right]
=p​(1−p)(1−2​p)2.absent𝑝1𝑝superscript12𝑝2\displaystyle=\frac{p(1-p)}{(1-2p)^{2}}.

The LDP guarantees of the 2RR is obtained from the fact that e−ϵ0≤1≤1−pp≤eϵ0superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ011𝑝𝑝superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ0e^{-\epsilon_{0}}\leq 1\leq\frac{1-p}{p}\leq e^{\epsilon_{0}} for any p∈(0,1/2]𝑝012p\in(0,1/2]. Furthermore, we can prove that the 2RR satisfies (α,ϵ​(α))𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼\left(\alpha,\epsilon(\alpha)\right)-RDP, where ϵ​(α)italic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon\left(\alpha\right) is given by:

ϵ​(α)=1α−1​log⁡(pα​(1−p)1−α+p1−α​(1−p)α),italic-ϵ𝛼1𝛼1superscript𝑝𝛼superscript1𝑝1𝛼superscript𝑝1𝛼superscript1𝑝𝛼\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\left(p^{\alpha}(1-p)^{1-\alpha}+p^{1-\alpha}(1-p)^{\alpha}\right), (25)

where this bound is obtained from the definition of the RDP and also given in [6]. This completes the proof of Theorem 1. ■■\blacksquare

Next we present the following lemma which is useful for bounding the privacy parameter, ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}, parameter of our mechanisms which depend on the binary randomized response.

Lemma 5.

(Privacy parameter)  For any v>0𝑣0v>0, by setting p=12​(1−v2v2+4)𝑝121superscript𝑣2superscript𝑣24p=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\sqrt{\frac{v^{2}}{v^{2}+4}}\right), the 2RR mechanism with parameter p𝑝p satisfies ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP, where ϵ0≤vsubscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑣\epsilon_{0}\leq v.

Proof.

From Theorem 1, the 2RR mechanism with parameter p<1/2𝑝12p<1/2 is ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP, where ϵ0=log⁡(1−pp)subscriptitalic-ϵ01𝑝𝑝\epsilon_{0}=\log\left(\frac{1-p}{p}\right). Hence, it is sufficient to prove that ϵ0=log⁡(1−pp)≤vsubscriptitalic-ϵ01𝑝𝑝𝑣\epsilon_{0}=\log\left(\frac{1-p}{p}\right)\leq v when choosing p=12​(1−v2v2+4)𝑝121superscript𝑣2superscript𝑣24p=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\sqrt{\frac{v^{2}}{v^{2}+4}}\right) for any v≥0𝑣0v\geq 0.

Appendix B Proofs of Theorem 7 and Theorem 8 (Binary vectors)

In this section, we prove Theorem 7 and Theorem 8 for the mean of binary vectors in local DP and MMS models, respectively.

B-A Communication Bound for Theorem 7 and Theorem 8

Observe that each client sends s𝑠s messages; each message consists of a pair (ai​j,yi​j)subscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗\left(a_{ij},y_{ij}\right), where ai​jsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗a_{ij} is drawn uniformly at random from ⌈ds⌉𝑑𝑠\lceil\frac{d}{s}\rceil values and yi​jsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗y_{ij} is a binary elements. Hence, each message requires log⁡(⌈ds⌉)+1𝑑𝑠1\log\left(\lceil\frac{d}{s}\rceil\right)+1 bits. As a result the total communication bits per client is given by s​(log⁡(⌈ds⌉)+1)𝑠𝑑𝑠1s\left(\log\left(\lceil\frac{d}{s}\rceil\right)+1\right)-bits.

B-B Privacy of the local DP model in Theorem 7

In the mechanism ℛp,sBinsubscriptsuperscriptℛBin𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p,s}, each client sends s𝑠s messages of the 2RR mechanism ((ai​1,yi​1),…,(ai​s,yi​s))subscript𝑎𝑖1subscript𝑦𝑖1…subscript𝑎𝑖𝑠subscript𝑦𝑖𝑠\left(\left(a_{i1},y_{i1}\right),\ldots,\left(a_{is},y_{is}\right)\right) with parameter p=12​(1−ϵ02/s2ϵ02/s2+4)𝑝121superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02superscript𝑠2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ02superscript𝑠24p=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\sqrt{\frac{\epsilon_{0}^{2}/s^{2}}{\epsilon_{0}^{2}/s^{2}+4}}\right). Hence, from Lemma 5, each message is ϵ0ssubscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑠\frac{\epsilon_{0}}{s}-LDP. As a results, the total mechanism ℛp,sBinsubscriptsuperscriptℛBin𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p,s} is ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP from the composition of the DP mechanisms [28].

In addition, we can bound the RDP of the mechanism ℛp,sBinsubscriptsuperscriptℛBin𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p,s} in the local DP model by using the composition of the RDP (see Lemma 1). From the proof of Theorem 1 in Appendix A, the 2RR mechanism is (α,ϵ​(α))𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼\left(\alpha,\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\right)-RDP, where ϵ​(α)italic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon\left(\alpha\right) is bounded by:

ϵ​(α)=1α−1​log⁡(pα​(1−p)1−α+p1−α​(1−p)α),italic-ϵ𝛼1𝛼1superscript𝑝𝛼superscript1𝑝1𝛼superscript𝑝1𝛼superscript1𝑝𝛼~{}\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\left(p^{\alpha}(1-p)^{1-\alpha}+p^{1-\alpha}(1-p)^{\alpha}\right), (27)

In the mechanism ℛp,sBinsubscriptsuperscriptℛBin𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p,s}, each client sends s𝑠s messages of the 2RR mechanism. Hence, the mechanism ℛp,sBinsubscriptsuperscriptℛBin𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p,s} is (α,s​ϵ​(α))𝛼𝑠italic-ϵ𝛼\left(\alpha,s\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\right)-RDP, where ϵ​(α)italic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon\left(\alpha\right) is given is (27).

B-C Privacy of the MMS model in Theorem 8

In the mechanism ℛp,sBinsubscriptsuperscriptℛBin𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p,s}, each client sends s𝑠s messages of the 2RR mechanism ((ai​1,yi​1),…,(ai​s,yi​s))subscript𝑎𝑖1subscript𝑦𝑖1…subscript𝑎𝑖𝑠subscript𝑦𝑖𝑠\left(\left(a_{i1},y_{i1}\right),\ldots,\left(a_{is},y_{is}\right)\right). We assume that there exist s𝑠s shuffler, where the j𝑗j-th shuffler randomly permutes the set of messages {(ai​j,yi​j):i∈[n]}conditional-setsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖𝑗𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\left\{\left(a_{ij},y_{ij}\right):i\in[n]\right\} from the n𝑛n clients. Hence from composition of the RDP, it is sufficient to bound the RDP of shuffling n𝑛n outputs of the 2RR mechanism.

We use the recent results of privacy amplification by shuffling in [7], which states the following

Lemma 6.

[7] For any n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}, ϵ0>0subscriptitalic-ϵ00\epsilon_{0}>0, and α𝛼\alpha such that α4​e5​ϵ0≤n9superscript𝛼4superscript𝑒5subscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑛9\alpha^{4}e^{5\epsilon_{0}}\leq\frac{n}{9}, the output of shuffling n𝑛n messages of an ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP mechanism is (α,ϵ​(α))𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼\left(\alpha,\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\right)-RDP, where ϵ​(α)italic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon\left(\alpha\right) is bounded by:

ϵ​(α)≤1α−1​log⁡(1+α​(α−1)​2​(eϵ0−1)2n)≤2​α​(eϵ0−1)2nitalic-ϵ𝛼1𝛼11𝛼𝛼12superscriptsuperscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ012𝑛2𝛼superscriptsuperscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ012𝑛\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\leq\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\left(1+\alpha(\alpha-1)\frac{2\left(e^{\epsilon_{0}}-1\right)^{2}}{n}\right)\leq 2\alpha\frac{\left(e^{\epsilon_{0}}-1\right)^{2}}{n} (28)

Recently [8] improved the dependence on ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0} of the result in  [7] by showing the following.

Lemma 7.

[8][Corollary 4.3]  For any n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N}, ϵ0>0subscriptitalic-ϵ00\epsilon_{0}>0, and α≤n16​ϵ0​eϵ0𝛼𝑛16subscriptitalic-ϵ0superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ0\alpha\leq\frac{n}{16\epsilon_{0}e^{\epsilon_{0}}}, the output of shuffling n𝑛n messages of an ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP mechanism is (α,ϵ​(α))𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼\left(\alpha,\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\right)-RDP, where ϵ​(α)italic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon\left(\alpha\right) is bounded by:

ϵ​(α)≤α​c​(eϵ0−1)2n​eϵ0,italic-ϵ𝛼𝛼𝑐superscriptsuperscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ012𝑛superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\leq\alpha\frac{c\left(e^{\epsilon_{0}}-1\right)^{2}}{ne^{\epsilon_{0}}}, (29)

for some universal constant c𝑐c.

From Theorem 1, each message of the client is ϵ0=log⁡(1−pp)subscriptitalic-ϵ01𝑝𝑝\epsilon_{0}=\log\left(\frac{1-p}{p}\right)-LDP. Hence, from Lemma 7, the output of one shuffler is (α,ϵ~​(α))𝛼~italic-ϵ𝛼\left(\alpha,\tilde{\epsilon}\left(\alpha\right)\right)-RDP, where ϵ~​(α)≤c​α​(1−2​p)2n​p​(1−p)~italic-ϵ𝛼𝑐𝛼superscript12𝑝2𝑛𝑝1𝑝\tilde{\epsilon}\left(\alpha\right)\leq c\alpha\frac{(1-2p)^{2}}{np(1-p)}. Thus, from composition, the output of the s𝑠s shufflers is (α,ϵ​(α))𝛼italic-ϵ𝛼\left(\alpha,\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\right)-RDP, where ϵ​(α)italic-ϵ𝛼\epsilon\left(\alpha\right) is bounded by:

ϵ​(α)≤c​α​s​(1−2​p)2n​p​(1−p).italic-ϵ𝛼𝑐𝛼𝑠superscript12𝑝2𝑛𝑝1𝑝~{}\epsilon\left(\alpha\right)\leq c\alpha\frac{s(1-2p)^{2}}{np(1-p)}. (30)

Observe that  (30) gives a closed form bound on the RDP of the mechanism ℛp,sBinsubscriptsuperscriptℛBin𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p,s} in the shuffle model. However, we can numerically provide better bound on the RDP of the shuffle model using [8]. Now, we use Lemmas 2 to convert from RDP to central DP. For given δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, shuffling the outputs of n𝑛n mechanisms ℛp,sBinsubscriptsuperscriptℛBin𝑝𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\text{Bin}}_{p,s} is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP, where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is bounded by

ϵ≤2​s​(1−2​p)2​log⁡(1/δ)n​p​(1−p).italic-ϵ2𝑠superscript12𝑝21𝛿𝑛𝑝1𝑝~{}\epsilon\leq 2\sqrt{\frac{s(1-2p)^{2}\log(1/\delta)}{np(1-p)}}. (31)

By setting p=12​(1−v2v2+4)𝑝121superscript𝑣2superscript𝑣24p=\frac{1}{2}\left(1-\sqrt{\frac{v^{2}}{v^{2}+4}}\right) and v2=n​ϵ24​s​log⁡(1/δ)superscript𝑣2𝑛superscriptitalic-ϵ24𝑠1𝛿v^{2}=\frac{n\epsilon^{2}}{4s\log(1/\delta)}, we can easily show that (31) is satisfied, and hence, the output of the shufflers is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP.

Appendix C Properties of Quantization scheme

In this section, we prove some properties of the quantization scheme proposed in Section IV-A for vector 𝐳i∈[0,1]dsubscript𝐳𝑖superscript01𝑑\mathbf{z}_{i}\in[0,1]^{d}. We first prove some properties for a scalar case when x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1], and then, the results of the bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty} will be obtained directly from repeating the scalar case on each coordinate.

Let x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1] and x(k)=∑l=1sbl​2−lsuperscript𝑥𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑠subscript𝑏𝑙superscript2𝑙x^{(k)}=\sum_{l=1}^{s}b_{l}2^{-l} for k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1, where x(0)=0superscript𝑥00x^{(0)}=0 and bk=⌊2k​(x−xk−1)⌋subscript𝑏𝑘superscript2𝑘𝑥superscript𝑥𝑘1b_{k}=\lfloor 2^{k}(x-x^{k-1})\rfloor. For given m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1, we represent x𝑥x using m𝑚m bits as follows: x~(m)=∑k=1m−1bk​2−k+u​2−m+1superscript~𝑥𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚1subscript𝑏𝑘superscript2𝑘𝑢superscript2𝑚1\tilde{x}^{(m)}=\sum_{k=1}^{m-1}b_{k}2^{-k}+u2^{-m+1}, where u=𝖡𝖾𝗋𝗇​(2m−1​(x−x(m−1)​[j]))𝑢𝖡𝖾𝗋𝗇superscript2𝑚1𝑥superscript𝑥𝑚1delimited-[]𝑗u=\mathsf{Bern}\left(2^{m-1}(x-x^{(m-1)}[j])\right). This estimator needs only m𝑚m bits of representation.

Lemma 8.

For given x∈[0,1]𝑥01x\in[0,1], let x~(m)superscript~𝑥𝑚\tilde{x}^{(m)} be the quantization of x𝑥x presented above. We have that x~(m)superscript~𝑥𝑚\tilde{x}^{(m)} is an unbiased estimate of x𝑥x with bounded MSE:

𝖬𝖲𝖤scalarquan=supx∈[0,1]𝔼​[‖x−x~(m)‖22]≤14m,subscriptsuperscript𝖬𝖲𝖤quanscalarsubscriptsupremum𝑥01𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑥superscript~𝑥𝑚221superscript4𝑚\mathsf{MSE}^{\text{quan}}_{\text{scalar}}=\sup_{x\in[0,1]}\mathbb{E}\left[\|x-\tilde{x}^{(m)}\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\frac{1}{4^{m}}, (36)

where the expectation is taken over the randomness in the quantization scheme.

=xi,absentsubscript𝑥𝑖\displaystyle=x_{i},

where step (a) is obtained from the fact that u𝑢u is a Bernoulli random variable with bias p=2m−1​(x−x(m−1))𝑝superscript2𝑚1𝑥superscript𝑥𝑚1p=2^{m-1}(x-x^{(m-1)}). We show that the estimator x~(m)superscript~𝑥𝑚\tilde{x}^{(m)} has a bounded MSE by 4−msuperscript4𝑚4^{-m}:

Corollary 1.

For given a vector 𝐳i∈[0,1]dsubscript𝐳𝑖superscript01𝑑\mathbf{z}_{i}\in[0,1]^{d}, let 𝐳~i(m)superscriptsubscript~𝐳𝑖𝑚\tilde{\mathbf{z}}_{i}^{(m)} be the quantization of 𝐳isubscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}_{i} by applying the above scalar quantization scheme on each coordinate 𝐳i​[j]subscript𝐳𝑖delimited-[]𝑗\mathbf{z}_{i}[j] for j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d]. Then, 𝐳~i(m)superscriptsubscript~𝐳𝑖𝑚\tilde{\mathbf{z}}_{i}^{(m)} is an ubiased estimate of 𝐳isubscript𝐳𝑖\mathbf{z}_{i} with bounded MSE:

𝖬𝖲𝖤vectorquan=sup𝐳i∈[0,1]d𝔼​[‖𝐳i−𝐳~i(m)‖22]≤d4m,subscriptsuperscript𝖬𝖲𝖤quanvectorsubscriptsupremumsubscript𝐳𝑖superscript01𝑑𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐳𝑖subscriptsuperscript~𝐳𝑚𝑖22𝑑superscript4𝑚\mathsf{MSE}^{\text{quan}}_{\text{vector}}=\sup_{\mathbf{z}_{i}\in[0,1]^{d}}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathbf{z}_{i}-\tilde{\mathbf{z}}^{(m)}_{i}\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\frac{d}{4^{m}}, (39)

where the expectation is taken over the randomness in the quantization scheme.

Appendix D Proofs of Theorem 2 and Theorem 3 (Bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm vectors)

In this section, we prove Theorem 2 and Theorem 3 for the mean of bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm vectors in local DP and shuffle models, respectively.

D-A Communication Bound for Theorem 2 and Theorem 3

In the mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ∞subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{\infty}}_{v,m,s}, the client sends m𝑚m binary vectors 𝐛i(1),…,𝐛i(m−1),𝐮isuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖1…superscriptsubscript𝐛𝑖𝑚1subscript𝐮𝑖\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(1)},\ldots,\mathbf{b}_{i}^{(m-1)},\mathbf{u}_{i} using the private mechanism ℛp,sBinsuperscriptsubscriptℛ𝑝𝑠Bin\mathcal{R}_{p,s}^{\text{Bin}}. From Theorem 7 and Theorem 8, the private mechanism ℛp,sBinsuperscriptsubscriptℛ𝑝𝑠Bin\mathcal{R}_{p,s}^{\text{Bin}} needs log⁡(⌈ds⌉)+1𝑑𝑠1\log\left(\lceil\frac{d}{s}\rceil\right)+1 bits for communication. Thus, the total communication of the private mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ∞subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{\infty}}_{v,m,s} is m​s​(log⁡(⌈ds⌉)+1)𝑚𝑠𝑑𝑠1ms\left(\log\left(\lceil\frac{d}{s}\rceil\right)+1\right)-bits.

D-C Privacy of the MMS model in Theorem 3

Appendix E Proofs of Theorem 4 and Theorem 5 (Bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vectors)

In this section, we prove Theorem 4 and Theorem 5 for the mean of bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vectors in local DP and shuffle models, respectively.

In the mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s}, each client applies random rotation to her vector 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} and then applies the private mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ∞subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{\infty}}_{v,m,s} to the bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm vector 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}. Hence the communication and privacy are the same as the private mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ∞subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{\infty}}_{v,m,s}. Thus, it remains to prove the MSE bound for both local DP model and shuffle model.

E-A MSE bound of the local DP model (Theorem 4) and shuffle model (Theorem 5)

The proofs are obtained directly from the MSE of the bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm vector in Theorem 2 and Theorem 3 with the following Theorem about the random rotation matrix.

Theorem 10.

[45] Let U=1d​𝐇​D𝑈1𝑑𝐇𝐷U=\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}\mathbf{H}D, where 𝐇𝐇\mathbf{H} denotes Hadamard matrix and D𝐷D is a diagonal matrix with i.i.d. uniformly ranodom {±1}plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\} entries. Let 𝐱1,…,𝐱n∈𝔹2d​(r2)subscript𝐱1…subscript𝐱𝑛superscriptsubscript𝔹2𝑑subscript𝑟2\mathbf{x}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{n}\in\mathbb{B}_{2}^{d}\left(r_{2}\right) be bounded ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm vectors and m​a​t​h​b​f​wi=U​𝐱i𝑚𝑎𝑡ℎ𝑏𝑓subscript𝑤𝑖𝑈subscript𝐱𝑖\\ mathbf{w}_{i}=U\mathbf{x}_{i}. With probability at least 1−β1𝛽1-\beta, we have that

maxi∈[n]⁡‖𝐰i‖∞=maxi∈[n]⁡‖U​𝐱i‖∞≤10​r2​log⁡(n​dβ)d.subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscriptnorm𝑈subscript𝐱𝑖10subscript𝑟2𝑛𝑑𝛽𝑑\max_{i\in[n]}\|\mathbf{w}_{i}\|_{\infty}=\max_{i\in[n]}\|U\mathbf{x}_{i}\|_{\infty}\leq 10r_{2}\sqrt{\frac{\log(\frac{nd}{\beta})}{d}}. (49)

From Lemma 10, the vector 𝐰i=U​𝐱isubscript𝐰𝑖𝑈subscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{w}_{i}=U\mathbf{x}_{i} is bounded ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}-norm of radius r∞=10​r2​log⁡(n​dβ)dsubscript𝑟10subscript𝑟2𝑛𝑑𝛽𝑑r_{\infty}=10r_{2}\sqrt{\frac{\log(\frac{nd}{\beta})}{d}} with probability at least 1−β1𝛽1-\beta. Hence, by plugging the radius r∞=10​r2​log⁡(n​dβ)dsubscript𝑟10subscript𝑟2𝑛𝑑𝛽𝑑r_{\infty}=10r_{2}\sqrt{\frac{\log(\frac{nd}{\beta})}{d}} into Theorem 4, we obtained the MSE in Theorem 4. Similarly, by plugging the radius r∞=10​r2​log⁡(n​dβ)dsubscript𝑟10subscript𝑟2𝑛𝑑𝛽𝑑r_{\infty}=10r_{2}\sqrt{\frac{\log(\frac{nd}{\beta})}{d}} into Theorem 3, we obtained the MSE in Theorem 5.

E-B Lower bounds

A lower bound for local DP model was proposed in [11] in Theorem 2.12.12.1 stated.

Theorem 11 (Lower Bound For local DP model [11]).

Let n,d∈ℕ𝑛𝑑ℕn,d\in\mathbb{N} and ϵ0>0subscriptitalic-ϵ00\epsilon_{0}>0. For any 𝐱1,…,𝐱n∈𝔹2d​(r2)subscript𝐱1…subscript𝐱𝑛superscriptsubscript𝔹2𝑑subscript𝑟2\mathbf{x}_{1},\ldots,\mathbf{x}_{n}\in\mathbb{B}_{2}^{d}(r_{2}), the MSE is bounded below by:

𝖬𝖲𝖤LDPℓ2=Ω​(r22​dn​min⁡{ϵ02,ϵ0,b})superscriptsubscript𝖬𝖲𝖤LDPsubscriptℓ2Ωsuperscriptsubscript𝑟22𝑑𝑛subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ20subscriptitalic-ϵ0𝑏\mathsf{MSE}_{\text{LDP}}^{\ell_{2}}=\Omega\left(\frac{r_{2}^{2}d}{n\min\left\{\epsilon^{2}_{0},\epsilon_{0},b\right\}}\right) (50)

for any unbiased algorithm ℳℳ\mathcal{M} that is ϵ0subscriptitalic-ϵ0\epsilon_{0}-LDP with b𝑏b-bits of communication per client.

Our lower bound for the shuffle model in Theorem 6 is a combination of the lower bound on DME with communication constraints proposed in [1] and the lower bound on DME with central (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP constraints proposed in [38].

Appendix F Application to private stochastic optimization for federated learning

In this section, we exploit our private mechanisms for DME to give convergence guarantees for DP-SGD algorithm. We consider a standard SGD algorithm, where the server initialize the model by choosing θ0∈𝒞superscript𝜃0𝒞\theta^{0}\in\mathcal{C}. At the t𝑡t-th iteration, the server chooses uniformly at random a subset of clients of size k∈[n]𝑘delimited-[]𝑛k\in[n] and sends the current model θtsuperscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{t} to the sampled clients. Let 𝒮t⊂[n]subscript𝒮𝑡delimited-[]𝑛\mathcal{S}_{t}\subset[n] denotes the set of sampled clients at the t𝑡t-th iteration. Each sampled client i∈𝒮t𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡i\in\mathcal{S}_{t} computes the local gradient ∇Fi​(θt)∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta^{t}\right). Then, the client applies our private ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s} mechanism before sending it to the shufflers. The sever received the shuffled messages and aggregates the private gradients and updates the model as follows:

θt+1=θt−η​gt,superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡𝜂subscript𝑔𝑡\theta^{t+1}=\theta^{t}-\eta g_{t}, (51)

where gt=𝒜ℓ2​({𝒴i:i∈𝒮t})subscript𝑔𝑡superscript𝒜subscriptℓ2conditional-setsubscript𝒴𝑖𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡g_{t}=\mathcal{A}^{\ell_{2}}\left(\{\mathcal{Y}_{i}:i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}\}\right) denotes the private estimate of the true average gradients ht=1k​∑i∈𝒮t∇Fi​(θt)subscriptℎ𝑡1𝑘subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡h_{t}=\frac{1}{k}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta^{t}\right). We present a standard results for convergence of the SGD algorithm for smooth non-convex functions.

Theorem 12 (SGD convergence [24]).

Let F𝐹F be L𝐿L-smooth and ∀θ​‖∇F​(θ)‖2≤Dfor-all𝜃subscriptnorm∇𝐹𝜃2𝐷\forall\mathbf{\theta}\|\nabla F\left(\theta\right)\|_{2}\leq D. Let θ0superscript𝜃0\theta^{0} satisfies F​(θ0)−F​(θ∗)≤DF𝐹superscript𝜃0𝐹superscript𝜃subscript𝐷𝐹F\left(\theta^{0}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\leq D_{F}. Let ℛℛ\mathcal{R} be a private-compression scheme and η=min⁡{L−1,2​DF​(σ​L​T)−1}𝜂superscript𝐿12subscript𝐷𝐹superscript𝜎𝐿𝑇1\eta=\min\left\{L^{-1},\sqrt{2D_{F}}\left(\sigma\sqrt{LT}\right)^{-1}\right\}. Then after T𝑇T iterations, we get:

𝔼t∼Unif​(T)​[∇F​(θt)]≤2​DF​LT+2​2​L​DF​σT+D​B,subscript𝔼similar-to𝑡Unif𝑇delimited-[]∇𝐹superscript𝜃𝑡2subscript𝐷𝐹𝐿𝑇22𝐿subscript𝐷𝐹𝜎𝑇𝐷𝐵\mathbb{E}_{t\sim\text{Unif}\left(T\right)}\left[\nabla F\left(\theta^{t}\right)\right]\leq\frac{2D_{F}L}{T}+\frac{2\sqrt{2}\sqrt{LD_{F}}\sigma}{\sqrt{T}}+DB, (52)

where σ2=2​max1≤t≤T⁡2​𝔼​[ht−∇F​(θt)]+2​max1≤t≤T⁡2​𝔼​[gt−ht]superscript𝜎22subscript1𝑡𝑇2𝔼delimited-[]subscriptℎ𝑡∇𝐹superscript𝜃𝑡2subscript1𝑡𝑇2𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑡subscriptℎ𝑡\sigma^{2}=2\max_{1\leq t\leq T}2\mathbb{E}\left[h_{t}-\nabla F\left(\theta^{t}\right)\right]+2\max_{1\leq t\leq T}2\mathbb{E}\left[g_{t}-h_{t}\right] and B=max1≤t≤T⁡‖𝔼​[gt−ht]‖2𝐵subscript1𝑡𝑇subscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑡subscriptℎ𝑡2B=\max_{1\leq t\leq T}\|\mathbb{E}\left[g_{t}-h_{t}\right]\|_{2} denotes the maximum bias. htsubscriptℎ𝑡h_{t} is the stochastic gradient at the t𝑡tth iteration and gtsubscript𝑔𝑡g_{t} is the private-compressed gradient after applying the mechanisms ℛℛ\mathcal{R}. The expectation is taken with respect to the randomness of gradient and the private-compression mechanism ℛℛ\mathcal{R}.

The above theorem directly relates the MSE of the DME algorithm ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s} to the convergence of the SGD algorithm. We use this theorem along with privacy amplification by sub-sampling and strong composition theorem to derive the convergence of the DP-SGD algorithm described above.

Theorem 13 (DP-SGD convergence).

Let F𝐹F be L𝐿L-smooth and ∀θ​‖∇F​(θ)‖2≤Dfor-all𝜃subscriptnorm∇𝐹𝜃2𝐷\forall\mathbf{\theta}\|\nabla F\left(\theta\right)\|_{2}\leq D. Let θ0superscript𝜃0\theta^{0} satisfies F​(θ0)−F​(θ∗)≤DF𝐹superscript𝜃0𝐹superscript𝜃subscript𝐷𝐹F\left(\theta^{0}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\leq D_{F}. Let ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s} be our private-compression scheme and η=min⁡{L−1,2​DF​(σ​L​T)−1}𝜂superscript𝐿12subscript𝐷𝐹superscript𝜎𝐿𝑇1\eta=\min\left\{L^{-1},\sqrt{2D_{F}}\left(\sigma\sqrt{LT}\right)^{-1}\right\}. By choosing v2=k​ϵ~2s​log⁡(k​T/n​δ)superscript𝑣2𝑘superscript~italic-ϵ2𝑠𝑘𝑇𝑛𝛿v^{2}=\frac{k\tilde{\epsilon}^{2}}{s\log(kT/n\delta)} and ϵ~=n​ϵk​T​log⁡(2/δ)~italic-ϵ𝑛italic-ϵ𝑘𝑇2𝛿\tilde{\epsilon}=\frac{n\epsilon}{k\sqrt{T\log\left(2/\delta\right)}}, then after T𝑇T iterations, the total algorithm is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP. Furthermore, we get:

𝔼t∼Unif​(T)​[∇F​(θt)]≤𝒪​(L​d​DF​log⁡(2​n/δ)n​ϵ)subscript𝔼similar-to𝑡Unif𝑇delimited-[]∇𝐹superscript𝜃𝑡𝒪𝐿𝑑subscript𝐷𝐹2𝑛𝛿𝑛italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}_{t\sim\text{Unif}\left(T\right)}\left[\nabla F\left(\theta^{t}\right)\right]\leq\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{L\sqrt{dD_{F}\log\left(2n/\delta\right)}}{n\epsilon}\right) (53)
Proof.

Privacy analysis: Let q=k/n𝑞𝑘𝑛q=k/n denote the sampling ratio at each iteration. At each iteration, we apply our private mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s} with parameter v2=k​ϵ~2s​log⁡(k​T/n​δ)superscript𝑣2𝑘superscript~italic-ϵ2𝑠𝑘𝑇𝑛𝛿v^{2}=\frac{k\tilde{\epsilon}^{2}}{s\log(kT/n\delta)}. Hence, from Theorem 5, the output of the shuffling at the t𝑡t-th iteration is (ϵ~,n​δk​T)~italic-ϵ𝑛𝛿𝑘𝑇\left(\tilde{\epsilon},\frac{n\delta}{kT}\right)-DP. since, we sample k𝑘k out of n𝑛n clients at the t𝑡t-th round, then we get that the privacy budget of the t𝑡t-th iteration is (ϵt,δT)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡𝛿𝑇\left(\epsilon_{t},\frac{\delta}{T}\right)-DP from privacy amplification by sub-sampling [42], where ϵt=log⁡(1+q​(eϵ~−1))subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡1𝑞superscript𝑒~italic-ϵ1\epsilon_{t}=\log\left(1+q\left(e^{\tilde{\epsilon}}-1\right)\right). Note that ϵt=𝒪​(q​ϵ~)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡𝒪𝑞~italic-ϵ\epsilon_{t}=\mathcal{O}\left(q\tilde{\epsilon}\right) when ϵ~≤1~italic-ϵ1\tilde{\epsilon}\leq 1. Now by using the strong composition theorem, get that our mechanism is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿\left(\epsilon,\delta\right)-DP, where ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is bounded by:

ϵ≤2​T​log⁡(2/δ)​ϵt+T​ϵt​(eϵt−1).italic-ϵ2𝑇2𝛿subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡𝑇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡1\epsilon\leq\sqrt{2T\log\left(2/\delta\right)}\epsilon_{t}+T\epsilon_{t}\left(e^{\epsilon_{t}}-1\right). (54)

Observe that ϵ=𝒪​(T​log⁡(2/δ)​ϵt)italic-ϵ𝒪𝑇2𝛿subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon=\mathcal{O}\left(\sqrt{T\log\left(2/\delta\right)}\epsilon_{t}\right)when ϵt≤1Tsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑡1𝑇\epsilon_{t}\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}. By choosing ϵ~=n​ϵk​T​log⁡(2/δ)~italic-ϵ𝑛italic-ϵ𝑘𝑇2𝛿\tilde{\epsilon}=\frac{n\epsilon}{k\sqrt{T\log\left(2/\delta\right)}}, we guarantees. This completes the proof of the privacy analysis.

Convergence analysis: The convergence analysis follows directly from the MSE bound of our mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s} in Theorem 5 and the convergence of the standard SGD algorithm in Theorem 12. ∎

Note that in our DP-SGD algorithm, we assume that each client compute the full gradient ∇Fi​(θt)∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta^{t}\right) and then applies the private-compression mechanism ℛv,m,sℓ2subscriptsuperscriptℛsubscriptℓ2𝑣𝑚𝑠\mathcal{R}^{\ell_{2}}_{v,m,s}.
